This is really 3.5 stars. Cozy, dark and a small space. I had my most recent birthday dinner here with 4 friends. My friend who recommended the restaurant had raved about the meatloaf and YES, it was as good as it was talked up to be. Light, not too dense and heavy and a great flavor, and definitely worth going back for. Mac and cheese was so-so. Everyone else enjoyed what they ordered (mostly meatloaf). A nice happy dinner for everyone!

Blue Plate has been a great restaurant over the years. I have been remiss in not reviewing it earlier. They have a few starters that are wonderful including the grilled squid and the pork belly. I have also loved their porterhouse pork chop and the steak with the spicy fries. I really love eating here and would recommend it ti anyone wanting an upscale dinner in Bernal Heights, you won't be disappointed!

Blue Plate continues to be a staple of mine since I moved to this city a year ago. I typically don't mention it to many because it's always reliably fantastic quality, fair prices & phenomenal service. What's better is that they're typically open for a last minute reservation too. My last experience, I was surprised that my meal was subpar. However, when the owner found out of my experience he contacted me directly to apologize, diagnose the problem (which happened to be the new chef forgot an important step in the basting process) and rectify the situation above and beyond my satisfaction.

My boyfriend and I were looking for a fun, delicious dinner on a Saturday night. Our friend recommended that we try Blue Plate. So glad we listened. It Turned into the perfect Saturday. Food was amazing (loved the fried chicken), wine was fantastic and reasonably priced, but my favorite part was the atmosphere. Fun but not too loud. Service was amazing!! I can't wait to sit in the backyard next time I visit.

I always wanted to go to this place, and a couple of weeks ago I finally did. The staff was friendly and the Hostess was very understanding (My friends and I were running at least thirty minutes late, oops). The place is on the small side (cozy), and the ambiance was stellar. The food was unique and tasty. The wine selection had a lot of variety to it. The only con, like all the other spots in their area, there was hardly any parking. However, there was a makeshift park and pay area set up at the Bank parking lot a few doors south. Don't worry; it was legitimate enough. The car was still there and safe when we returned.

Great food, great service! Get the heirloom tomato peach salad, fried chicken, and mac n' cheese. Trust me. You're welcome. It's a great spot to meet up with friends to have old school comfort food- without the heavy, gross feeling afterwards. Portions are bigg-ish and perfect for sharing. Try Blue Plate- it's a fantastic restaurant without the hype and nonsense.

Fried chicken--refried blackeyed beans, roasted pepper Big portions (strong seasoning...tasted this chicken all night & into the morning) I didn't touch the beans or the small green salad. I would have had to have been starving to finish my plate...or to believe I would go back to eat this chicken again. It's good but I will live without eating it again. Swung down here in hopes of eating their famed meatloaf. Me and my boyfriend split the gnocchi with rabbit and each ate a plate of the meatloaf. Verdict? Gnocchi was fluffy and flavorful with fresh parmesan and chunks of rabbit. Meatloaf was "not the way mom used to make it." Juicy with a huge chunk of meat next to a mound of soft mashed potatoes. Mmmm. Not a bad virgin taste of meatloaf. The desserts looked delicious but we were too stuffed to order!

In sixth grade, we had a substitute teacher. The lady walked in with a box of Kraft Macaroni & Cheese and told everyone that the student who behaved the best that day would "win" this glorious prize. For the entire day, I sat on the edge of my seat, politely raised my hand, and even helped the special-needs girl eat her snack at 10:30. Unfortunately, I displayed an "eat this b-e-y-o-t-ch-e-s" attitude during our afternoon spelling exercise. It wasn't my proudest moment. Needless to say, I wasn't the lucky winner of the coveted blue box. BUT, other classmates were even more upset that they didn't win. In fact, after the prize was awarded, two kids got suspended for fighting. (The winner was a girl named Sarah, who probably got beat-up later As this was a popular after-school activity for many of our town's finest). The macaroni & goat cheese at The Blue Plate is worth getting jumped by bullies. It's the greatest. Plus, the chicken & dumplings (which I have shied away from for 25+ years) make me feel happier than when I dropped 30 pounds, got my braces off, and my nickname changed from brainer to no-brainer.

Had the Braised rabbit gnocci and the grilled monterey bay squid. Both were terrific. Fried Chicken was juicy and tender with excellent flavor. I would definitely recommend this restaurant. I need to come back and try the hanger steak!

Two words sums up my experience: Mild Disappointment. The meal started out well enough, with 3 appetizers to share around the table. We had the Grilled Hearts of Romaine, the Grilled Monterey Bay Squid, and the Gnocchi With Braised Spring Rabbit. The first two, were very good, though the squid was bathed in too much lemon for my taste. The gnocchi was awesome - light and fluffy, with a very savory sauce with small chunks of rabbit. It's a minor pity they only serve the gnocchi in appetizer portions. For the entrees, I shared a House-made Tagliatelle and a Painted Hills Ribeye. The tagliatelle wasn't bad, but the flavor was so subtle the only bit that stood out were the pine nuts. The ribeye was cooked to a medium rare, but there was quite a bit of char on the outside, and the horseradish sauce was pretty much necessary to mask it. I also tried some of the Crispy Smoked Chicken, and while the combo of chicken and oatmeal works well the chicken isn't all that impressive. I vaguely remember having some kind of chocolate brownie with ice cream and something else for dessert. Let's just say they were solid, but obviously not very memorable. So on the appetizers alone, I'd give this place a 4. But given the price and the overall fooding experience, it's more of a 3 in my book. Last thing: one of the entree prices was wrong in their computer, so we were initially overcharged. Can't really knock the waitress for that, but gotta wonder how many people didn't notice their bill and paid a few bucks more than they should have...

I was almost in tears. The double-cut pork chop was so good, the balance of flavors so perfect, smoky, and juicy, with the sauerkraut and mustard.... I LITERALLY (I'm NOT kidding) was tearing up. My eyes glazed over. rolled back into my head. you know what I'm talking about. And the elk grove pinot went perfectly with it. The only well lit sign in front is a little neon blue one saying, simply, "EAT". I. hear. and. obey. Walking into the restaurant you're immediately immersed in that smell of charred flesh from a backyard bbq... mouthwateringly awesome. even if you weren't hungry before, you'd be hungry at that smell. Sitting in the front was a little cramped, and the smoke from the grill which was right there, would probably get in your clothes (it wasn't too bad though). But service was good and friendly. And the food blew my mind in its perfect balance. The salad my companion had was cabbage and apples, with some sharp cheddar cubes. The mac and cheese with drunken goat cheese... did not disappoint my imagination's wildest fantasy. I had a roasted bone marrow appetizer... it was good, but there wasn't enough marrow. Just 3 small bones. Could have used about 5-6 bones for the size of the toast, and the price.. You spread it on little grilled pieces of toast, and eat it with fresh parsley and radishes arranged on the plate. The pork chop... damn. That is the finest pork chop I've had in this city. And I'm chinese... we eat lots of pork chops. IT came with a smoked bratwurst, sauerkraut, and this great honeymustard type sauce on top that was just strong/spicy enough, and just sweet enough, and just creamy enough to complement the pork chop. Be wary though, those of you that are faint of heart. The pork chop is not cooked all the way through (Read: medium most parts, rare/medium rare at the bone), so if you are afraid of the raw flesh, ask them to cook it more. It might not be as juicy as what I had though.... you have been warned. Meat was perfectly marinated and flavorful. While the desserts sounded good, we opted to walk a block away to Mitchell's... ;) Perfect location =D Overall, the food was good, 4-star level, except that ambrosia worthy pork chop, which automatically kicks it up to 5 stars. PROPS to the incomparable Dunzo S, for recommending this place to me. She is one of my favorites, and I always trust her recs.

Living in SF, it's easy to become a "distance snob." Hell, before living here, I used to think driving back and forth from SJ to SF was no big deal. Now I throw a fit when my car has to leave the garage. So with that in mind, I was just WAITING for Blue Plate to irritate me since I had to drive ALL THE WAY to Bernal Heights. I literally was looking for things to bitch about when I got there and to my dismay, Blue Plate didn't give me anything to work with. Bastards. How dare they serve the most delicious meat loaf I have ever tasted? How dare they serve a mac & cheese side dish laced with drunken goat cheese? How dare they get me drunk on really good wine and.... Oh hell, you get the point. The place is friggin' delicious and worth the drive. Make a reso though, it's small and gets packed up. Kmart.

Here are the things I ate and/or tasted on the night that 6 of us went here for dinner. - Romaine Salad: really bad. Bland. Boring. Blech!! (This was what I had ordered.) - Beet Salad: EXCELLENT, sweet, and LOTS of beets. (This was Rob's, so I offered him my salad, and took his Beets. I'm generous like that.) - Clam Appetizer: We shared this family-style. Strange flavor - rather spicy, but mediocre taste. And then the entrees... Well - - between the appetizer and entrees, there was a wait. A long, long wait. In fact, so long that I aged 3 years while waiting for my entree................................ - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - Really, no joke, I was full from the appetizers, and was starving by the time the entrees came out. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - ------ -- - - - - - --? - - - ?? - - - - ?????????? Finally..................... - Meatloaf: Decent, not too bad. - Steak: I'd bet my right hand that the sauce was - - - get a load of this - - - A1 Sauce. Seriously. I dare you to try the $29 Steak and tell me it's NOT A1 Sauce. Served with fries that were really good. How was the steak, you ask? Are you kidding, are you not following me here? It was COVERED IN A1 SAUCE - how would I know how the steak was? - Pork Tenderloin: Juicy meat, exactly two small pieces, which was strange considering all the other portioning was rather generous. Served with mashed polenta concoction. Meat was good, accompaniments were decent. For sides, we ordered some Goat Cheese Mac and Cheese, discovered the kitchen doesn't believe in using SALT. We also ordered Asparagus, and the theory was confirmed. SALT! Dessert: They ran out of the Strawberry Rhubarb Cake that I had intended to try. So then I wanted the Banana Cream Pie. Out of that, too. Well there was nothing else appetizing on there, so I skipped dessert and drank an Americano which was OK, at best. All in all, Blue Plate disappointed on many levels. Honestly, if the meal had taken 2 hours, I'd have left satisfied since I did come here to catch up with friends. At 2.5 hours, I'd have been disturbed from sitting there too long, but it might be acceptable. The meal, from start to finish, took over 3 hours. The wine list was actually quite nice, and I had a glass of Riesling, a glass of Cotes du Rhone, and took many, many sips of this outstanding IPA that they served. The final bill came to $409 including tip which they added, which makes it a $68 per person meal - and that's with two girls not drinking. Seriously - - are you KIDDING me!?!?! It's too bad, too, because I liked the atmosphere, and the convenience of being able to park at the BOA parking lot (for a nominal $10). There's a neon blue sign outside of Blue Plate that reads: "EAT". I feel like running over there to hang another red sign right below it: "SOMEWHERE ELSE!"

And so for my 600th review, I'd like to pick something so unique, so special that o, only 213 other people have reviewed before me. Really this restaurant is special because it represents a very San Francisco vibe with the closest of my San Francisco friends. Paul M picked this plate to take a very good friend out to dinner. It wasn't until the bill came that I realized that we take this friend out for his birthday every year and yet he seemed to miss my birthday last year and the year before advocated buying me unnecessary, inappropriate items and cheap items from Good Vibrations over the list of kitchen treasures I put together on my list for my guests and registered at Crate & Barrel. Hmpf. Character of certain guests aside, this place is a worthy place to take any one on their birthday or just you when you deserve a nice dinner without runaway prices. We were saddened not be able to sit outside so request this with your reservation and do get a reservation, friends, this is no hidden gem despite its out of the way location amidst everyday neighborhood joints, everyone knows as the magnanimity of the reviews suggests. The golden beet salad was my first course and a real masterpiece. Beets, particularly golden beets, need to be prepared with a chemist's careful eye and they were "beets as light as air" as Dolly Levi would say before signing. These beets give you something to sing about. The rest of our table enjoyed their well presented, wisely portioned meals as we enjoyed delicious red wine from France. It helps that the aforementioned birthday boy who becomes an apparition at my birthday was French. Well you know what they say about those french. The dinner itself, the lovely dessert and the sweetness of the waitress was so nice in fact, I think I might want to stop here for my next birthday. Perhaps I should firm up the guest list now and maybe, just maybe I'll invite you for a little taste of loveliness.

Unique little gem in an unexpected neighborhood. It's not that mission doesn' have great food, but this place feels like it belongs in Hays or Noe, it's just that cozy and cute. The squid appetizer is a must! The sausage is good too, but not as impressive. The gnochi are surprisingly light and their broth is just as delicate. The patio area is a great touch and I'm sure is wonderful on a warm SF night. Sitting by the window is just as romantic though! Also, parking lot a few doors away. Sweet.

An old favorite that I hadn't visited in awhile. Came back tonight and it was as good as I remembered. We shared the meatloaf and fried chicken and both dishes were great! Highly recommend. Will definitely be back again soon!

This little diamond in the serious rough of Mission at Valencia St. is a gem. (Ooh, "diamond," "gem." It's a little early on in the review for puns that bad. Sorry.) Anyway. I bought my parents Kooza tickets for Christmas. Because I know my dad falls asleep at anything past 8 o'clock, I got them matinee tickets. They live in the Napa Valley, so this was a big day out down in the city for them. They told me to pick the restaurant and they'd treat me to dinner after the show. Blue Plate's gourmet comfort food genre sounded like my mom to a tee, Mrs. "nothing's better than my homemade meatloaf with a side of mac and cheese." So I booked a table. We rolled up at 8 on a Saturday night. The place was rammed and I'm glad I had booked ahead. Upon walking in the front door, the delicious smell hits you like a delicious ton of delicious bricks. I want Blue Plate incense to burn in my house but I'm afraid constantly smelling the combination of bacon, goat cheese, and warm foccaccia bread would quickly cause me to pile on the pounds. I'll settle for the occasional visit to Blue Plate. Anybody who has ever been to brunch with me knows my affinity for bacon. I've been known to order multiple sides of bacon and coffee for brunch and that's it. So when I saw a bacon appetizer I knew I was home. So to speak. If you're not a veg, don't walk out of Blue Plate without trying this dish. I really think I'll order at least two of them the next time. I've been known to make entire dinners from appetizers. The meatloaf, as my mom said, rivals hers. The ribeye is as big as my head and my dad actually had to take half of it home. I don't think I've ever seen that happen before. The macaroni and cheese was made with goat cheese. Why doesn't this happen more often? My mom didn't stop talking about the chocolate dessert. Even the next day on the phone she brought it up. I want to sit in the enchanted back garden but I'll wait until spring.

Really bad service!!.. Got there at 6pm for a party of 10 people, got seated at 6:30pm. We had to do a set menu of 3 course because of big party. 1st course came out at 7:30pm, 2nd course came out at 8:15pm, 3rd course came out at 9:45pm. We didn't get out of there until 10:30pm... I don't know about you, but when I'm having dinner I would like to have my food served on a timely manner. We were so hungry by the time the entrees came out we were all to tired to eat from waiting for 4 1/2 hours. The worst part was that there were other parties that arrived after us, and was done eating and out the door 2 hours before ours. Very very disappointed especially when this place has pretty decent reviews. NOT coming back for sure..

Blue Plate is the Victorian era to The Front Porch's Roaring 20s. The BP is a solid gem in the Outer Mission. As awesome as The FP is, they'll never have the adorably romantic outside tables or peaceful, easy atmosphere that has won the BP it's special place in my heart. What The BP is good for: -first dates (and dates in general) -Comfort Food prepared with fresh local goodness -outdoor dining on nippy nights (thanks to the abundant heat lamps) -dinner with parents -dinner with out-of-towners -meatloaf/mashed potato combo -small groups (like 4 max) -Pork Belly -short wait time (now, thanks to the FP) I love, love, love the meatloaf and mashed potatoes, but the rest of the menu was uninspiring on my last visit. They do the old stand-bys SO SO well...the grilled hearts of romaine have won MY heart and they do magical things with soup. They have a decent selection of wines by the glass, including *sparkling* wine, just in case that's the way you roll (and I do). Eat the meatloaf. Only good things happen when you eat the meatloaf. And the grilled lettuce. And soup. And remember to order enough for leftovers. You will want more in the morning. Trust me...I learned the hard way so that you don't have to.

    In sixth grade, we had a substitute teacher.  The lady walked in with a box of Kraft Macaroni & Cheese and told everyone that the student who behaved the best that day would "win" this glorious prize.  For the entire day, I sat on the edge of my seat, politely raised my hand, and even helped the special-needs girl eat her snack at 10:30.  Unfortunately, I displayed an "eat this b-e-y-o-t-ch-e-s" attitude during our afternoon spelling exercise.  It wasn't my proudest moment.  Needless to say, I wasn't the lucky winner of the coveted blue box.

    BUT, other classmates were even more upset that they didn't win.  In fact, after the prize was awarded, two kids got suspended for fighting. (The winner was a girl named Sarah, who probably got beat-up later  As this was a popular after-school activity for many of our town's finest).

    The macaroni & goat cheese at The Blue Plate is worth getting jumped by bullies.  It's the greatest.  Plus, the chicken & dumplings (which I have shied away from for 25+ years) make me feel happier than when I dropped 30 pounds, got my braces off, and my nickname changed from brainer to no-brainer.

    Two words sums up my experience: Mild Disappointment.

    The meal started out well enough, with 3 appetizers to share around the table.  We had the Grilled Hearts of Romaine, the Grilled Monterey Bay Squid, and the Gnocchi With Braised Spring Rabbit.  The first two, were very good, though the squid was bathed in too much lemon for my taste.  The gnocchi was awesome - light and fluffy, with a very savory sauce with small chunks of rabbit.  It's a minor pity they only serve the gnocchi in appetizer portions.

    For the entrees, I shared a House-made Tagliatelle and a Painted Hills Ribeye.  The tagliatelle wasn't bad, but the flavor was so subtle the only bit that stood out were the pine nuts.  The ribeye was cooked to a medium rare, but there was quite a bit of char on the outside, and the horseradish  sauce was pretty much necessary to mask it.  I also tried some of the Crispy Smoked Chicken, and while the combo of chicken and oatmeal works well the chicken isn't all that impressive.

    I vaguely remember having some kind of chocolate brownie with ice cream and something else for dessert.  Let's just say they were solid, but obviously not very memorable.

    So on the appetizers alone, I'd give this place a 4.  But given the price and the overall fooding experience, it's more of a 3 in my book.

    Last thing: one of the entree prices was wrong in their computer, so we were initially overcharged.  Can't really knock the waitress for that, but gotta wonder how many people didn't notice their bill and paid a few bucks more than they should have...

    2/4/2007

    I was almost in tears.  The double-cut pork chop was so good, the balance of flavors so perfect, smoky, and juicy, with the sauerkraut and mustard....  I LITERALLY (I'm NOT kidding) was tearing up.  My eyes glazed over.  rolled back into my head.  you know what I'm talking about.  And the elk grove pinot went perfectly with it.

    The only well lit sign in front is a little neon blue one saying, simply, "EAT".  I. hear. and. obey.  Walking into the restaurant you're immediately immersed in that smell of charred flesh from a backyard bbq... mouthwateringly awesome.  even if you weren't hungry before, you'd be hungry at that smell.  

    Sitting in the front was a little cramped, and the smoke from the grill which was right there, would probably get in your clothes (it wasn't too bad though).  But service was good and friendly.  And the food blew my mind in its perfect balance.

    The salad my companion had was cabbage and apples, with some sharp cheddar cubes.  The mac and cheese with drunken goat cheese... did not disappoint my imagination's wildest fantasy.  I had a roasted bone marrow appetizer... it was good, but there wasn't enough marrow.  Just 3 small bones.  Could have used about 5-6 bones for the size of the toast, and the price..  You spread it on little grilled pieces of toast, and eat it with fresh parsley and radishes arranged on the plate.

    The pork chop... damn.  That is the finest pork chop I've had in this city.  And I'm chinese... we eat lots of pork chops.  IT came with a smoked bratwurst, sauerkraut, and this great honeymustard type sauce on top that was just strong/spicy enough, and just sweet enough, and just creamy enough to complement the pork chop.  Be wary though, those of you that are faint of heart.  The pork chop is not cooked all the way through (Read:  medium most parts, rare/medium rare at the bone), so if you are afraid of the raw flesh, ask them to cook it more.  It might not be as juicy as what I had though.... you have been warned.  Meat was perfectly marinated and flavorful.  

    While the desserts sounded good, we opted to walk a block away to Mitchell's... ;)  Perfect location =D

    Overall, the food was good, 4-star level, except that ambrosia worthy pork chop, which automatically kicks it up to 5 stars.

    PROPS to the incomparable Dunzo S, for recommending this place to me.  She is one of my favorites, and I always trust her recs.

    4/22/2008

    Here are the things I ate and/or tasted on the night that 6 of us went here for dinner.

    - Romaine Salad: really bad.  Bland.  Boring.  Blech!!  (This was what I had ordered.)
    - Beet Salad:  EXCELLENT, sweet, and LOTS of beets.  (This was Rob's, so I offered him my salad, and took his Beets.  I'm generous like that.)
    - Clam Appetizer:  We shared this family-style. Strange flavor - rather spicy, but mediocre taste.

    And then the entrees...
    Well - - between the appetizer and entrees, there was a wait.

    A long, long wait.

    In fact, so long that I aged 3 years while waiting for my entree................................

    - - - -

    - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

    Really, no joke, I was full from the appetizers, and was starving by the time the entrees came out.

    - - - - - - - - -

    - - - - - - - - -  - - -     ------  -- - - - - -  --? - - - ??   - - - - ??????????

    Finally.....................

    -  Meatloaf:  Decent, not too bad.
    -  Steak:  I'd bet my right hand that the sauce was - - - get a load of this - - - A1 Sauce.  Seriously.  I dare you to try the $29 Steak and tell me it's NOT A1 Sauce.  Served with fries that were really good.  How was the steak, you ask?  Are you kidding, are you not following me here?  It was COVERED IN A1 SAUCE - how would I know how the steak was?
    -  Pork Tenderloin:  Juicy meat, exactly two small pieces, which was strange considering all the other portioning was rather generous.  Served with mashed polenta concoction.  Meat was good, accompaniments were decent.

    For sides, we ordered some Goat Cheese Mac and Cheese, discovered the kitchen doesn't believe in using SALT.  We also ordered Asparagus, and the theory was confirmed.  SALT!

    Dessert:
    They ran out of  the Strawberry Rhubarb Cake that I had intended to try.  So then I wanted the Banana Cream Pie.  Out of that, too.  Well there was nothing else appetizing on there, so I skipped dessert and drank an Americano which was OK, at best.

    All in all, Blue Plate disappointed on many levels.   Honestly, if the meal had taken 2 hours, I'd have left satisfied since I did come here to catch up with friends.  At 2.5 hours, I'd have been disturbed from sitting there too long, but it might be acceptable.  The meal, from start to finish, took over 3 hours. The wine list was actually quite nice, and I had a glass of Riesling, a glass of Cotes du Rhone, and took many, many sips of this outstanding IPA that they served.  

    The final bill came to $409 including tip which they added, which makes it a $68 per person meal - and that's with two girls not drinking.
    Seriously - - are you KIDDING me!?!?!

    It's too bad, too, because I liked the atmosphere, and the convenience of being able to park at the BOA parking lot (for a nominal $10).

    There's a neon blue sign outside of Blue Plate that reads: "EAT".
    I feel like running over there to hang another red sign right below it:  "SOMEWHERE ELSE!"

    5/31/2007

    And so for my 600th review, I'd like to pick something so unique, so special that o, only 213 other people have reviewed before me.
    Really this restaurant is special because it represents a very San Francisco vibe with the closest of my San Francisco friends.

    Paul M picked this plate to take a very good friend out to dinner.

    It wasn't until the bill came that I realized that we take this friend out for his birthday every year and yet he seemed to miss my birthday last year and the year before advocated buying me unnecessary, inappropriate items and cheap items from Good Vibrations over the list of kitchen treasures I put together on my list for my guests and registered at Crate & Barrel.  Hmpf.

    Character of certain guests aside, this place is a worthy place to take any one on their birthday or just you when you deserve a nice dinner without runaway prices.

    We were saddened not be able to sit outside so request this with your reservation and do get a reservation, friends,  this is no hidden gem despite its out of the way location amidst everyday neighborhood joints, everyone knows as the magnanimity of the reviews suggests.

    The golden beet salad was my first course and a real masterpiece.
    Beets, particularly golden beets, need to be prepared with a chemist's careful eye and they were "beets as light as air" as Dolly Levi would say before signing.  These beets give you something to sing about.  

    The rest of our table enjoyed their well presented, wisely portioned meals as we enjoyed delicious red wine from France.  It helps that the aforementioned birthday boy who becomes an apparition at my birthday was French.  Well you know what they say about those french.

    The dinner itself, the lovely dessert and the sweetness of the waitress was so nice in fact, I think I might want to stop here for my next birthday.  Perhaps I should firm up the guest list now and maybe, just maybe I'll invite you for a little taste of loveliness.

    1/21/2008

    This little diamond in the serious rough of Mission at Valencia St. is a gem.

    (Ooh, "diamond," "gem." It's a little early on in the review for puns that bad. Sorry.)

    Anyway.

    I bought my parents Kooza tickets for Christmas. Because I know my dad falls asleep at anything past 8 o'clock, I got them matinee tickets. They live in the Napa Valley, so this was a big day out down in the city for them. They told me to pick the restaurant and they'd treat me to dinner after the show. Blue Plate's gourmet comfort food genre sounded like my mom to a tee, Mrs. "nothing's better than my homemade meatloaf with a side of mac and cheese." So I booked a table.

    We rolled up at 8 on a Saturday night. The place was rammed and I'm glad I had booked ahead. Upon walking in the front door, the delicious smell hits you like a delicious ton of delicious bricks. I want Blue Plate incense to burn in my house but I'm afraid constantly smelling the combination of bacon, goat cheese, and warm foccaccia bread would quickly cause me to pile on the pounds. I'll settle for the occasional visit to Blue Plate.

    Anybody who has ever been to brunch with me knows my affinity for bacon. I've been known to order multiple sides of bacon and coffee for brunch and that's it. So when I saw a bacon appetizer I knew I was home. So to speak. If you're not a veg, don't walk out of Blue Plate without trying this dish. I really think I'll order at least two of them the next time. I've been known to make entire dinners from appetizers.  

    The meatloaf, as my mom said, rivals hers.
    The ribeye is as big as my head and my dad actually had to take half of it home. I don't think I've ever seen that happen before.
    The macaroni and cheese was made with goat cheese. Why doesn't this happen more often?
    My mom didn't stop talking about the chocolate dessert. Even the next day on the phone she brought it up.

    I want to sit in the enchanted back garden but I'll wait until spring.

    11/3/2006

    Blue Plate is the Victorian era to The Front Porch's Roaring 20s. The BP is a solid gem in the Outer Mission. As awesome as The FP is, they'll never have the adorably romantic outside tables or peaceful, easy atmosphere that has won the BP it's special place in my heart.
    What The BP is good for:
    -first dates (and dates in general)
    -Comfort Food prepared with fresh local goodness
    -outdoor dining on nippy nights (thanks to the abundant heat lamps)
    -dinner with parents
    -dinner with out-of-towners
    -meatloaf/mashed potato combo
    -small groups (like 4 max)
    -Pork Belly
    -short wait time (now, thanks to the FP)

    I love, love, love the meatloaf and mashed potatoes, but the rest of the menu was uninspiring on my last visit. They do the old stand-bys SO SO well...the grilled hearts of romaine have won MY heart and they do magical things with soup. They have a decent selection of wines by the glass, including *sparkling* wine, just in case that's the way you roll (and I do). Eat the meatloaf. Only good things happen when you eat the meatloaf. And the grilled lettuce. And soup. And remember to order enough for leftovers. You will want more in the morning. Trust me...I learned the hard way so that you don't have to.
